reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-claim in the essay’s argument against WAM-convergence: that if internalism is true, people may avoid learning/believing the correct moral view because it would motivate costly action. This is only one support among many (externalism, antirealism-driven divergence, power concentration, lock-in, threats, etc.), so even fully defusing it would not greatly change the essay’s overall conclusions (moderate centrality). The critique has some force: internalism doesn’t by itself imply agents can reliably prevent moral belief formation, and the step from ‘moral belief is motivating’ to ‘people will choose not to learn/believe’ is not entailed and needs more psychological/institutional story. Still, the essay only claims ‘might’/plausibility and motivated avoidance/doxastic insulation is psychologically common, so the critique only partially undercuts the point (moderate-low strength). The critique’s main claims are broadly correct, though it likely over-assumes stable truth-tracking institutions and understates motivated cognition/avoidance dynamics (good but not perfect correctness). It is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Internalism does not imply agents can stably avoid moral belief formation
